clean_story:
Trusting the news. Forgetting its flaws.

Named after physicist Murray Gell-Mann, who noticed how people dismiss errors in other news sources—but forget the same flaws in their own trusted ones.

Imagine reading a headline like "Scientists Discover Miracle Cure!"—then later learning it was exaggerated. You’d scoff at the outlet that ran it. But if your favorite news site published the same fluff? You’d likely shrug it off.
The effect works because our brains treat trusted sources like a favorite restaurant’s "secret recipe. " Even if the soup tastes off one day, we blame the chef’s "bad day"—not the recipe itself.
Studies show this bias strengthens with repetition and emotional attachment. A 2018 MIT study found false news spreads 6x faster than truth—especially when it aligns with preexisting beliefs.
The fix? Treat all news like a used car inspection: check the brakes (sources), kick the tires (cross-reference), and ignore the shiny paint (headlines).

Cognitive dissonance.
Confirmation bias.
The backfire effect.
